name: building construction, budget hotel | building, budget hotel | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20858/documentation

This dataset represents a tourist accommodation facility classed as a budget hotel (comfort category 3*), located in Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil. It was first opened in 1982 as a brand new urban hotel. The hotel has capacity to host 108 people and offers rooms of the following types (total number of rooms is given in brackets): suites (16) and double (40). The hotel has 9 floors which host a lobby, a restaurant, a meeting room and a small parking lot behind the building exclusively for employees.The laundry is outsourced. The hotel occupies a total area of 826,67 m2. The average annual occupancy of the hotel is estimated to be 50% which is equal to 20440 guest nights per year. The load bearing structure of hotel building is made of concrete and the facade is made of concrete and brickwork.

This dataset is modelled to include the inputs for the construction of a hotel building. This includes:energy and water used in construction, land transformation, building structure and outer building shell, foundations, inner walls, roofs, ceiling and windows, doors, floors, finishing and painting, bathroom equipment. Activities include hotel building construction with lifeframe of the hotel building of 75 years. Maintenance is included only through the consideration of the lifetime of the different exchanges. For example, windows are assumed to have a lifetime of 35 years, therefore the exchange amount is multiplied by 75years / 35 years=2.14.

Activities end with 1 unit of hostel building, including maintenance. Due to data availability, the following building construction processes have been excluded: mirror, urinary, shower, cables, gutter, drains, ventilation.
category: F:Construction/41:Construction of buildings/410:Construction of buildings/4100:Construction of buildings

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The survey was done in the year 2017 with the data provided covering the operational year 2016-2017.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The hostel is based in the city of Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The level of technology is considered current. The load bearing structure of hotel building is made of concrete and the facade is made of concrete and brickwork.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: In terms of construction, the amounts of input material are calculated based on usage across all instances within the hotel building.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Primary data from the hotel supplemented with literature-based calculations and estimates, where appropriate.

flow.name: building, budget hotel
flow.category: F:Construction/41:Construction of buildings/410:Construction of buildings/4100:Construction of buildings

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). Combined of all instances of use across the building floor. Assuming 12.3 kg of tiles is required to cover 1 m2 of floor area. Source:  Victoria Plumbing 2018. British ceramic tile. Available from: https://victoriaplum.com/product/british-ceramic-tile-metro-bevel-white-gloss-tile-100mm-x-200mm Accessed 16 March 2018. Assumed service life of 5 years for floor ceramic tile which is equivalent to the period of major refurbishments in hotels. Source: Filimonau et al. 2011. Reviewing the carbon footprint analysis of hotels: Life Cycle Energy Analysis (LCEA) as a holistic method for carbon impact appraisal of tourist accommodation. Journal of Cleaner Production, 19(17-18), 1917-1930. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to insert waste.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. 

Combined of all instances of use across the building structure, walls (m2) and floor (3501.5m3). Assumed thickness of 225 mm, Available at http://kingspaninsulation.co.uk/getattachment/5fdd04b2-e58e-4622-97bb-5861799ab02a/Thermafloor-TF70-pdf.pdf Accessed on 10 Feb 2018 Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout.

Additionally the concrete for foundations is accounted for (164.27m3). Estimated value based on the hotel area. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste concrete.

exchanges.description: Estimated value. For window glass: Assuming each room has two windows. Assumed size of a standard 2020 window of 0.37 m2, https://modernize.com/windows/standard-sizes Assuming 15 kg of window glass is required to cover 1m2 of area (double-glazed windows).  For construction glass: Assuming density of glass 2.6 kg/m3. Available from https://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/density-solids-d_1265.html Accessed 16 March 2018. Assumed average service life of 20 years for both types. Source: Howard et al. 2007. Comparative service life assessment of window systems. Available from: http://www.fwpa.com.au/images/marketaccess/PR07.1047%20Final%20Report%20WEB.pdf Accessed 16 March 2018. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste glass.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Used here in place of marble. Combined of all instances of use across the building. Assumed thickness of marble is 22 mm. Source: Erdly and Schwartz 2004. Building facade maintenance, repair, and inspection. ASTM International, West Conshohocken, USA. Assumed density of marble is 2.7 kg/m3. Source: The Engineering Toolbox 2018. Densities of common solids. Available from: https://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/density-solids-d_1265.html Accessed 25 March 2018. Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to inert waste.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Assuming that 0.5 kl per 1 m2 of floor area (AFA) is required in building construction. Source: Crawford et al. 2005. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to wastewater. Value double checked in McCormack, et al. 2007.

Reference:

Crawford, Robert and Treloar, Graham 2005, An assessment of the energy and water embodied in commercial building construction, in Australian Life Cycle Assessment Conference (4th : 2005 : Novotel, Sydney, N.S.W.), Australian Life Cycle Assessment Society, Sydney, N.S.W., pp. 1-10. 

McCormack, et al. 2007. Modelling direct and indirect water requirements of construction. Building research & information. 35(2), 156-162.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). This flow represents ceramic washing basin and ceramic toilet seat. The hotel has 60 washing basins and 60 toilet seats. Washing basins are assumed to weigh 15kg (information taken from IKEA (2018) for the product "TÖRNVIKEN Countertop wash-basin", source retrieved from: http://www.ikea.com/gb/en/products/washstands-taps/wash-basins/t%C3%B6rnviken-countertop-wash-basin-white-art-90291518/, accessed 12 Feb 2018). The assumed lifetime is 15 years. Toilet seats are assumed to weigh 35kg (information taken from B&Q (2018) for the product "COOKE & LEWIS FABIENNE CLOSE-COUPLED TOILET WITH SOFT CLOSE SEAT", source retrieved from: https://www.diy.com/departments/cooke-lewis-fabienne-close-coupled-toilet-with-soft-close-seat/1142804_BQ.prd?B/R_Toilets_C_CT, accessed 12 Feb 2018).  In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to inert waste. 
In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to inert waste.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Used here in place of acustic tile as a more conventional product. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). Combined of all instances of use across the building structure, walls and ceiling. Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout. Assumed thickiness of glass wool 100 mm. Source: Knauf Insulation 2018. Knauf Insulation. Available from: http://www.knaufinsulation.co.uk/products/glass-mineral-wool-rolls/loft-insulation-rolls/earthwool-loft-roll-44 Accessed 16 March 2018. The density of glass wool is assumed to be 40 kg/m3 based on the specifications in ecoinvent dataset "glass wool mat production, CH 2000" accessed 22 Janaury 2018. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to waste glass.
